doc.headline: Man rescued after months in snow-covered car
doc.post:
Wow... Just wow!
Man rescued after months in snow-covered car
A man was pulled alive from a snowed-in car on a deserted forest road in northern Sweden where he had been stranded and without food for at least two months in freezing temperatures, police said.
"We received word yesterday (Friday) that a person had been found in a snow-covered car deep in the woods, more than 1.5 kilometres (nearly a mile) from the main road," Ebbe Nyberg, a duty officer in the northern Vaesterbotten county, told AFP.
A man on a snowscooter had noticed the top of the car on the deserted and snowfilled forest road, not far from the northern town of Umeaa, just south of the Arctic Circle, and after clearing off some of the snow had peered inside.
"He saw movement and realised there was probably a person in there and called the police," Nyberg said, adding that rescue services and an ambulance that had been belted to drive on the snow had rushed to the scene.
They were amazed at what they found: A man in his mid-40s huddled inside in a sleeping bag "in really bad shape," starving and barely able to move or speak
Nyberg said it was unclear exactly how long the man, who is from the central Swedish town of Oerebro, had been stuck, but pointed out that the car must have been driven to the deserted spot "before it began snowing in the autumn."
"He says himself he has been without food since December, so we think he must have got there around then, or perhaps earlier, in November," he said, pointing out that temperatures in the area have recently plunged as low as minus 30 degrees Celsius (-22 degrees Fahrenheit).
"It's just amazing he's alive!"
The man, who had not been reported missing and who has yet to say how he got stuck, appeared to have survived on nothing but snow since mid-December.
After his rescue, he was rushed to the Norrlands University Hospital, said Nyberg, who could provide no details on his condition.

For those of you who are doubtful about the dangers of deep snow and its sudden build up as well as its sudden changes of location, this just appeared on the internet news:
STEVENS PASS, Wash. — Three skiers were killed Sunday when an avalanche swept them about a quarter-mile down an out-of-bounds canyon at a popular resort, but a fourth skier caught up in the slide was saved by a safety device, authorities said.
The four were among three groups of skiers – about a dozen people in all – making their way through a foot and a half of fresh snow on the back side of Stevens Pass when the avalanche hit. Stevens Pass is in the Cascade Mountains, about 80 miles northeast of Seattle.
All were buried to some extent, but the men who died were swept approximately 1,500 feet down a chute in the Tunnel Creek Canyon area, King County Sheriff's Sgt. Katie Larson said.
Most of the other skiers, all well-equipped, were able to free themselves and rushed to dig out the victims. They performed CPR on the three men to no avail, Larson said.
The fourth skier who was swept down the mountain, a woman, appeared to avoid a similar fate because of the avalanche safety device she was wearing, Larson said.
Such devices include wearable airbags that can be deployed to help a person float atop an avalanche rather than being buried underneath it, or inflatable bags that create space between a person's mouth and the snow. It wasn't immediately known which kind the woman had, said Deputy Chris Bedker of the sheriff's search-and-rescue unit.
The men who died were believed to be in their 30s and 40s.
"Most of the people involved in this were well-known to the ski community up here, especially to the ski patrol," Bedker said. "It was their friends who they recovered."
Initial reports of the avalanche reached the sheriff's office just after noon, and for some time it wasn't clear whether the other skiers had also been swept up in the slide.
The Northwest Weather and Avalanche Center on Sunday issued a warning for high avalanche danger for areas above 5,000 feet, saying warmer weather could loosen surface snow and trigger a slide on steeper slopes. The elevation of the avalanche wasn't immediately clear.
At mid-afternoon, the temperature at the base of the Stevens Pass ski resort was 24 degrees, with light winds and good visibility. The temperature at the top of the mountain was 22 degrees, according to the resort's website.
John Gifford, the ski area's general manager, said Sunday that the resort had received 19 inches of snow in the past 24 hours.
Stevens Pass is one of the most popular outdoor recreation areas in the state, with visitors flocking to the scenic site to go cross-country, back-country and downhill skiing, as well as snowshoeing and backpacking.

Weather can change really quick in the mountains. You can go from a sunny day to a white-out and a foot of fresh snow in the space of two hours. Here in the Cascades, further, the proximity to the ocean means there's a lot of moisture that's never far away. The Cascades divide the wet west from the dry and cold east of Washington and Oregon. When that cold air collides with wet air, you get snow. Lots and lots of wet, heavy snow. Happens more the higher up you go. Too many high mountain skiers have been caught for days in a sudden storm and cut off from any help. Can't do anything for them until the weather breaks. Often, it's too late.

doc.headline: Man Shoots Daughter's Laptop
doc.post:
Dad Shoots Daughter's Laptop Over Facebook Post [VIDEO]
By Sam Laird | Mashable ? 22 hrs ago
The disgruntled teenage daughter of a tech-savvy, gun-toting father just got a very public lesson in respecting one's elders.
"That right there is your laptop," the father, named Tommy Jordan, says in a YouTube video while pointing a video camera at a computer on laying in a patch of dirt and grass. "This right here is my.45," he says, moving a pistol into the frame.
He cocks the weapon and shoots nine exploding hollow-point rounds into the laptop.
Okay, rewind.
Jordan's 15-year-old daughter apparently wrote a Facebook post complaining about the chores she has to do at home and the overall hassle that her parents make her life. The father took exception to the public airing of grievances, and so decided to exact his own bit of public revenge, according to the video description, as well as Facebook and Reddit posts he appears to have made.
The role of social media in family life has been debated since social networks began to catch on, but Jordan appears to be taking a proactive approach.
In the video, which is titled "Facebook Parenting: For the troubled teen." and looks to be shot from a tripod, Jordan sits down in a chair outdoors with a computer print-out in hand. He dedicates the recording to his daughter and, "more importantly for all her friends on Facebook who thought that her little rebellious post was cute, and for all you parents out there who think your, you know, kids don't post bad things on Facebook."
Jordan says he works in IT for a living (and, indeed, appears to run a company called Twisted Networx) and chastises his daughter for thinking she could hide the note from him with privacy settings. He then reads the purported note aloud after explaining, "since you want to hide it from everyone, I'm going to share it with everybody."
In the note, the daughter says that she should be paid for the chores she does and her parents overwork her, criticizing them harshly. Jordan says that her complaints are mostly unjustified, and contrasts it to the work he had to do growing up.
After about seven minutes of preamble, he gets up from the chair and plugs the computer full of lead.
Jordan writes in the video description: "Maybe a few kids can take something away from this... If you're so disrespectful to your parents and yourself as to post this kind of thing on Facebook, you're deserving of some tough love. Today, my daughter is getting a dose of tough love."
Mashable has attempted to contact Jordan for further comment, but so far has not received a response.
Do you think this is an effective use of social media in parenting? Appropriate or inappropriate? Let us know in the comments. This story originally published on Mashable here.

A vintage used headband or hat is worn close to the head, and comes in contact with hairspray and cosmetics, it may also have accumulated a good amount of dust and dirt if it was not properly stored.
Did you take it to the Furrier and have it cleaned before you listed it?
Your " SOLD AS IS AND THERE IS NO RETURN" is trumped by Ebay and Paypal's buyer protection policies, so you do take returns and you do refund for a full 45 days after payment is received.
“As a general rule, if you want to get at the truth — hear both sides and believe neither.” Josh Billings

Apologise & offer a refund of purchase price & intial S&H upon return of the item. Make no metion of fb.
Meowkittykitty - Clearly I'm new here, so can you please explain your rationale? I'm trying to understand for my future sales. Thanks!!
Mac - For my own knowledge, did you include photos in your listing?
>^..^< The Cat Nanny

You can cheerfully refund upon return of item or
buyer can file SNAD, get their purchase price plus original shipping refunded by PP/ebay and you'll get a strike for having a disagreement filed.
btw - when you say "no returns' in listing, ebay considers that you don't want the item back and will refund without return of item.

my rationale was explained quite nicely by Desdam. If buyer files a SNAD claim, Ebay will refund the buyer & allow them to keep the item based on your no returns policy & you likely will be negged by the buyer. It is far easier to refund after getting your item back than stand on principle & be out the money and the item.
Pictures are a must. You should have them showing all aspects of the item. When I sold, I would use Photo Bucket to host them & put them in the body of my listings.

I looked at your hat listed. Were it mine, I would have pics of the veil spread out, close up of the top, inside, front, back & sides as well as the tags.
The same for the figurines, inside, bottom, back etc. You want to describe your items as if there were no pictures and have pictures as if there were no description.

Excellent advice Kitty, but I would add that one can't depend on common sense of the buyer either, if a vintage item is not spotlessly clean as it would be in brand new condition then this has to be mentioned also. Just a few lines saying that vintage items may not be as clean or as unused as brand new would do it, as long as you have those pictures. This is what is known as full disclosure, anything else gives a buyer grounds for a return, and these days that is enough to see you refunding a lot. At least if you disclose any condition flaws then you can say it was fully disclosed in the auction and the buyer bid and purchased it knowing the flaws. That is the only defense I have ever known of to work in a dispute but even that is not going to work every time if it happens too often.
Yes, I always post a picture.

You're not understanding about providing pictures. You need MORE pictures, showing the front, back, sides, inside, close ups of any unusual or damaged sections.
Buying eBay's picture services costs money. You can provide the pictures yourself for free by uploading your pictures to any online picture storage site. Photobucket is a reasonable choice. You can use it for free, or pay a small amount to get more featrues and possibly faster loading time.
To use the photobucket pictures in your Description, switch to the HTML version of your Description and paste the html link photobucket provides under each picture.
Switch back to the Text version of the Description to check how the pictures fit in your listing.

doc.headline: OT--Great horned owls hooting up a storm!
doc.post:
I love coming to the MISC forum on ebay when my insomnia kicks in. Don't usually post, but this is such a friendly board, I thought I'd tell everyone how wonderful it is right now, to hear the owls calling for mates.
I am a wildlife biologist and even tho I know that now is the time that owls start mating/nesting, it's still really cool to hear the symphony of sounds outside my window!

That is cool, I don't know that I have ever heard real owls make noise. I have seen some live owls with handlers & they seem to not like me. One kept staring at me even as it's handler moved away from me. Owls are cool but I am afraid that if one had the chance it would bite me.

Hey Meow--
Yes, one of them would bite you!
All raptors, birds of prey, have very strong beaks and really strong talons. In the past I had to capture wild falcons and they do not like being captured!
What is so interesting right now is that the owls are doing their thing, hooting and calling and possibly (having sex?) mating, and most of us sleep through it.

Hiyah we have 3 Owls with very DEEP hoooooooo's all 3 fly together and seem not to be scared of people...... one sits on our smaller tree what a site.... if you see a Owl look at the time usually they come back next day same time

We have wood duck nest boxes and Eastern screech owls love living in them. They usually have two or three little ones. The adult calls sound like tiny horse whinnys.....just amazing and well worth your time to Google,. Hearing owls are one of my favorite signs of spring.

That's good to hear. I love owls, and I hear them from time to time, but haven't seen one here in southern alabama.
I think they are magnificent creatures, I would love to see one.
We used to feed ducks when there may have been six to ten coming but when it got to 100, ( no lie) it was just too much to deal with. They have since moved on.

We have a local barn owl that swoops down as cars go by on the road sometimes...it is scary because it is unexpected. A bird that sounds weird to me is an eagle. One day I had my living room window open, and heard the strangest sounds. Opened the front door and 2 Bald Eagles were sitting in a tree... talking away to each other.

doc.headline: lost in mail
doc.post: i bought and paid for an axle for my motorcycle.the seller shipped the steel,heavy item in a bubble mailer envelope.i recieved the empty envelope with a hole in the end,and a usps sticker on it saying "recieved without contents".i emailed seller asking for his input but have gotten no reply.what should i do next?

Give the seller a couple of days to reply. If he does not, then if the envelope did not have any tracking or delivery confirmation, you can file a claim for "Item not received" (INR). If it does show a delivery confirmation, then file a claim for item "Significantly not as described" (SNAD).

hi,it had a delivery confirmation.not sure i understand your other option.i have saved the envelope with the usps sticker on it.never had this happen before,but it seems it must have occured to others.the guy did mail it and all,just didnt use good,common sense in putting a heavy pointed object in a paper envelope instead of a box.thanks again for any advice

If the Delivery Confirmation was scanned, then there's no point in filing a claim for 'Item not received" since the seller can show that something was delivered.
On the other hand, your item is invisible or missing, which is not as described. When a buyer files a SNAD claim, eBay will either issue a refund directly or might instruct the buyer to return the item for a full refund. You can ship your empty envelope back to him as a 3-ounce parcel with Delivery Confirmation for $1.64 (if you don't know how, just ask).

thehorseman1955,
As others have said you will not be getting your money back from the seller.
Your only option is to take the envelop, make a copy of the item (pic & description) and head to your local Post Office. You might call first and set up an appointment to talk to the postmaster.
I know that many an item gets caught up in their machinery and it ends up in lost and found section. At, the end of a sort, they find empty enevelops and boxes and items. They just have no way of matching items and containers to each other. So, they will send the container on.
The post master, hopefully, will know the steps in getting your widget back to you. They might need some form of proof of purchase, that is why I say call first.
Best of luck to you.

As others have said you will not be getting your money back from the seller.
If there was no Insurance on the package Nothing the Postmaster can do
I believe others said that if the OP opens a SNAD claim, They will get a FULL refund Item price + what they paid for the original shipping and handling
went something like >>
On the other hand, your item is invisible or missing, which is not as described. When a buyer files a SNAD claim, eBay will either issue a refund directly or might instruct the buyer to return the item for a full refund. You can ship your empty envelope back to him as a 3-ounce parcel with Delivery Confirmation for $1.64 (if you don't know how, just ask).
Delivery Confirmation is confirmation of delivery, not tracking. USPS scan form 5630 Guarantees you an acceptance scan and NOTHING else

doc.headline: Customer is either lying, scamming me or down right dumb
doc.post:
I sold an embroidery hoop (brand new) to a women a week ago. She emailed me today and said she received it but it is used and has scratches on it. She also said the hoop doesn't fit her machine. In the description, I listed the machine the hoop works with, so I asked her which machine she has. I assured her the hoop wasn't used and that we wouldn't have shipped out a damaged hoop. The only things I can think of is the package was damaged by the postal service during shipping (but that doesn't explain the hoop not fitting), she is lying (possibly a bate-and-switch scam), or she made a mistake and got the hoop for a machine that she doesn't own, so she is trying to blame me for that.
I am going to give her money back, but it makes me mad that this is happening. I do things right on ebay, I know how important it is to receive good products, so i try very hard to make what i ship out the best it can be. i have my main account plus this one that has only 3 ratings so far. if she leaves bad feedback, can i dispute it? this isn't in any way my fault. I ship products safely with lots of bubble wrap.
i can assure you (as readers) as well that the product was brand new and not damaged when it left my home. do i have the responcibility to return the money? please let me know what you think!
Make it clear to her she is required to return the item before you refund. Do not refund until you have the item in hand.
Oh dont worry, i said i would give her money back when we receive the hoop. i wouldnt be surprised if she jerks me around on this part of it...

Well, I don't think it is a bait and switch. Because your items don't sell for hundreds of dollars the way a Laptop would---for instance. So why would she take the risk of sending ou back a different prorduct?
She MIGHt be hoping to intimidate you into giving a refund without a return---because your feedback is so low---she may think you inexperienced---and do not know the rules.
You can of course, require a return at her expense---but that may well result in a Negative. It's too bad we can't look at her buying History---but you said she is new.
Oh, and if she leaves a Negative---it will not be removed. You cannot Dispute the Neg---because she claims item is damaged.

You can really drive yourself nuts trying to figure out her motivation for what she's saying.
Its easier to just say 'return for refund' and then move on and not worry about it until you receive the item back.

What's this 'customer''s feedback score?
Are there any indications of previous hassles with other sellers?
Ask her if the package appeared to be damaged or anything to that effect.
I once purchased a dress and for whatever reason, the package didn't get me on the first attempt. After several exchanged messages, the seller sent it again, and by this time the outside package appeared to be cracked and bent; but the dress was intact.
So I guess I was lucky on that occasion.

She claims the item is used (which it isn't) and that it doesn't fit her machine. She told me which machine she has and it isn't listed in the description. She said she is keeping the hoop and selling it to her friend (can't be that badly damaged if her friend wants it!)
She left neutral feedback and said the item wasn't as described. It was EXACTLY as described. She didn't read the description.
She probably won't reply to my email. At leats neutral feedback doesn't hurt my rating.

Even if the damage wasn't my fault? Any damage she claims happened in shipping.
She left neutral feedback. She keeps making different claims. The first was the item was used, second it was scratched, third it didn't fit her machine. The item was brand new, any damage occured during shipping, and she should have read the description before buying.
She probably won't reply to my last email. There's nothing I can do at this point, however I will reply to her feedback.
She has about 160 feebacks, and its 100% positive. Buyer error on this one.

I was in mail order for 25 years and think people put far too much faith in Feedback. I've got several hundred Feedbacks. So far I've got 100 pos., but I fully expect to get an occasional negative along the way. Likewise, I don't care if a person I deal with has a couple of negatives. So long as they aren't for dishonesty.
You can get negatives reversed. I've done it. Just keep all your e-mails & other paperwork and tell the truth when you dispute any negatives. So long as it appears you made every effort to treat the customer right you shouldn't have any trouble getting it reversed.

A slight correction to my above post:
I should have said "100% positive" rather than just "100 pos.". As Maxwell Smart, the originator of the term "Sorry about that" would say, "Sorry about that.".

doc.headline: Why do sellers mark up their items to prevent return?! Whats the point!
doc.post:
I've been a seller on eBay for probably around 5 years, before all of my email accounts, bank account, and my ebay acct., among others, were hacked by someone in Australia. I primarily sold, and honestly never really paid too much attention to other sellers practices, and how they sell their items etc...After all the hoopla with my accounts, I decided to open another ebay account, but not really to sell, at least not at the volume I used to. So now that I buy mostly on eBay, Ive noticed that a LOT of sellers mark through tags on clothing, luggage, purses, even SHOES to "prevent the buyer from returning the item to the retail store". Can someone PLEASE tell me the point in this frivolous action?
Most stores dont operate like Walmart, randomly giving out returns for items that are ages old and without any kind of proof of purchase. Most stores will not even give you a return without some kind of receipt, and if they do give you a refund, its for the "present" value, which wont be worth it to the person whose trying to return an item. You mark up items that 9/10 will not be able to be returned to the store, and more importantly, WHO CARES IF THEY TRY AND RETURN IT TO THE STORE?? How is this a reflection on the seller if the person who BIDS and WINS, AND PAYS for an item you had up for auction meanders to their nearest N.M or wherever to tries and return something? High end stores in no way are going to return an item that does not have a receipt. Try taking a Burberry bag to the nearest store w/o a receipt, and see if you have any luck returning it. It aint happenin. So why the helk would you intentionally mark up beautiful clothing and shoes or luggage with a big black permanent marker because you somehow, heroically, want to try and prevent some pathetic person who is going to try and make a few more bucks then what they paid for the item by returning the item? It doesn't make any sense, and honestly, for me, it makes me not want to buy their items when I see a huge permanent marking slashed trough beautiful leather tags...it makes no sense. I could understand if eBay was like Etsy, where every item is "supposedly" an original, and buyers attempt to resell it as their own. That's a whole different story all together. But for me to mark through a $700 pair of Burberry shoes, so I can prevent the person who paid $550 for it at my store from returning it, makes not a lick of sense. Who are you trying to protect? Burberry..or whoever? Yeah, I think there good without your "assistance".
Sellers out there, PLEASE tell me why do this. WHY?..there has got to be a better explanation from someone than "we are trying to prevent buyers from trying to return items that multi-gazillion dollar retailers made so they can attempt to make a few more dollars than they paid for it in my store." See how ridiculous that sounds?

High end stores in no way are going to return an item that does not have a receipt.
Most of the high-end stores around here do accept returns without a receipt. They will give you a mechandise credit or an exchange card, not cash.
I've never encountered a listing where the seller marks the tags but I have purchased some items that were marked before they were in the seller's possession.
Why is it so very important?

It's not the sellers. It's the retailers that drop the stuff off at goodwill or some other place, so they don't get it returned back to them.
During the Christmas season, I sometimes help out at the Target distribution center for 6 to 7 weeks. Anything that falls off the conveyor belt is automatically put in a goodwill pile just in case it got damaged inside. We then mark GW 2 or 3 times over it and/or either run a line thru the barcode or cut it off completely, depends on the item.
Walk in any thrift store around here that got clothes from a regular store, the tags are all crossed out.

Whether we say high end stores will take it back is here nor there. I dont know the return policy of every store, and Im sure most dont. The ones I have dealt with are not taking back merchandise not purchased from there store without full documentation and proof of purchase. Its so very important because I dont want to spend hundreds of dollars on an item only to have it slashed up with black permanent marker. It takes away from the item. Yeah, It matters. If others want to spend a bunch of $ on items and have it marked through, then that's their prerogative. Im not one of them, and Im sure Im not alone.

Its so very important because I dont want to spend hundreds of dollars on an item only to have it slashed up with black permanent marker. It takes away from the item.
Do you leave the tags on the item when you wear/use it?

The manufacturer often requires liquidation merchandise be marked or the label cut/cut out before it can be resold. Nothing the seller can do about that.
Although many stores have tightened their return policies, at one point some would take back just about anything no matter how worn and without a receipt. That is why the requirement was put in place and I think it just stands to this day.
I try to mention if I have something that has been marked or the label cut, but not all sellers do. If it is that important to you and the seller doesn't say, just ask them. That way you'll know.

Ebay is a secondary market, not retail, so there is no point in trying to buy things on here that you can return to a retail store for a full value refund. Retail stores mark through the original tags on items they are selling at clearance or donating, this is done to show the item is no longer being sold at full price and to prevent exactly the practice your talking about, which is someone paying very little on the secondary market and then getting a full value refund on that item by returning it.
So, let me get this clear, your mad because you cant' rip off retail sellers by returning items you buy on Ebay for full value? Wow!
Maybe they wont to look like Minnie Pearl and that black mark clashes with there look. HAHAHAHAHA
